Hello Ken-

I fully agree with your main point here. It is rather humbling that fitness
alone performs so poorly.  It is also cool that novelty search can overcome
that difficulty. That is an important discovery that you guys have made and
I am not trying to minimize that insight in the slightest.

I just like the idea of marrying Novelty Search and Fitness, as you say, for
practical purposes. I am also delighted that it seems (from Jean-Baptiste's
work) that the marriage does not drag Novelty Search down too much.


Cheers,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
jclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune




> From: kenstanley01 <kstanley@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Mon, 31 Aug 2009 03:44:26 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] Re: New paper "Novelty-based multiobjectivization"
> 
> Jeff, I agree that the novelty+fitness MOEA has good potential as a practical
> approach and should be interesting to follow.
> 
> However, I think there is an important facet of the novelty search results
> that goes beyond performance.  The idea that there are "huge classes of
> problems where pure Novelty search will not work" misses that it is a shock
> that it works in any serious domains at all!  Would you really expect a method
> that does not even know what it is looking for to solve *anything* better than
> fitness-based search?  Yet in fact we have been accumulating more and more
> domains where it does better.
> 
> Nevertheless, of course there are domains in which it will perform poorly.
> Yet the onus here should not be on novelty search, which does not purport to
> try to solve anything at all.  What I think is more interesting is the
> embarrassing result that fitness-based search is so inept against an algorithm
> that does not even know what it is looking for.  The whole thing is more of an
> indictment on the way we have been conducting search, and the way we have been
> interpreting learning algorithm results, than it is an endorsement of novelty
> search as the solution to all problems.
> 
> For example, in the past, when fitness-NEAT attempts to solve a problem and
> fails, we would have said the problem is NEAT.  Yet when novelty-NEAT solves
> the same problem seamlessly, the lie of the original interpretation is
> revealed.  In fact, there are many negative results for many algorithms that
> we should be questioning in light of novelty search.  We have been assuming
> that the fitness-based paradigm *is* learning, when it is only a small sliver
> of what learning can be.
> 
> I also do not think that expanding the maze 100 times would cause much
> problem, besides needing individual evaluations to last 100 times longer.  But
> the number of evaluations needed to evolve a solution would be about the same.
> Taking away the walls would cause it to need more evaluations, but I don't see
> it really causing a fundamental problem.  So I would dispute that it is as
> brittle as you say.
> 
> But the insight I'm raising is not about that anyway.  It's about the flaw in
> concluding too much from an attempt to optimize an objective about what a
> particular algorithm can accomplish.   If novelty might take longer without
> the walls, fitness will be even worse (longer time in deceptive traps).  In
> some sense, we are flirting with the futility of all of search.
> Novelty+fitness MOEA is likely a solution to some problems that neither one
> can solve alone, so it's a promising idea, but I think novelty search is
> significant for more than being a solution to something.  It is a symptom of a
> major interpretive problem that stretches back into EC history.
> 
> ken  
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@...> wrote:
>> 
>> Jean-Baptiste-
>> 
>> Thanks for writing this paper. It is really interesting.
>> 
>> I think it is particularly fascinating how well Novelty + Fitness
>> Multiobjective competed with pure Novelty search on a problem designed to
>> showcase the benefits of Novelty search.
>> 
>> My original instincts regarding Novelty search were that it was a great way
>> to overcome deception, but that there are huge classes of problems where
>> pure Novelty search will not work (e.g. take the problem you and the
>> original novelty search paper used, make it 1000 times larger, and get rid
>> of the bottom and left walls up to the first walls that jut in). I had
>> thought that a combination of Novelty + Fitness would be able to handle such
>> problems well, which your results strongly imply. Your paper suggests that
>> you will conduct tests on such problems. Have you tried that yet? I look
>> forward to seeing the results!
>> 
>> Cheers,
>> Jeff Clune
>> 
>> Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
>> jclune@...
>> www.msu.edu/~jclune
>> 
>> 
>> 
>> 
>>> From: Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor <mandor@...>
>>> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>> Date: Tue, 11 Aug 2009 16:12:37 +0200
>>> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
>>> Subject: [neat] New paper "Novelty-based multiobjectivization"
>>> 
>>>         Hello,
>>> 
>>> I just finished a paper for the IROS'09 workshop entitled "Exploring
>>> New Horizons in Evolutionary Design of Robots"
>>> [http://www.isir.fr/evoderob]. It's about novelty search and, since we
>>> talked a lot about it on this mailing-list, it could interest some of
>>> you.
>>> 
>>> Here is the paper:
>>> http://chronos.isir.upmc.fr/~mouret/papers/novelty_based_multiobjectivizatio
>>> n.
>>> pdf
>>> 
>>> Abstract:
>>>   Novelty search is a recent and promising approach to evolve
>>>   neuro-controllers, especially to drive robots. The main idea is to
>>>   maximize the novelty of behaviors instead of the efficiency.
>>>   However, abandoning the efficiency objective(s) may be too radical
>>>   in many contexts. In this paper, a Pareto-based multi-objective
>>>   evolutionary algorithm is employed to reconcile novelty search with
>>>   objective-based optimization by following a multiobjectivization
>>>   process. Several multiobjectivizations based on behavioral novelty
>>>   and on behavioral diversity are compared on a maze navigation
>>>   task. Results show that the multiobjectivizations is better at
>>>   fine-tuning behaviors than basic novelty search while keeping a
>>>   comparable number of iterations to converge.
>>> 
>>> Best regards,
>>> -- 
>>> Jean-Baptiste Mouret / Mandor
>>> tel : (+33) 6 28 35 10 49
